Authors:
María Laura Velez, Jorge Ariel Marfetan, María Eugenia
Salgado Salomón , Leonardo Enzo Taccari
Title:
Mortierella species from declining Araucaria araucana trees
in Patagonia, Argentina
Abstract:
Araucaria araucana is a native conifer to Argentina and
Chile that has a restricted distribution. In addition to its ecological
importance, A. araucana is relevant for its cultural and socioeconomic
aspects, being a key tree for the Mapuche indigenous people. This
species is endangered due to its uncontrolled logging, its excessive
harvesting of seeds, and the devastating fires that occurred during the
last two centuries. Since 2015, A. araucana has shown an unusual partial
death of the crown, but no evident primary pathogen or pest was
identified to be associated with the phenomenon. However, isolates of
Mortierella, a poorly studied fungal genus in Patagonia, were obtained
from the margins of necrotic phloem tissue of symptomatic trees. The aim
of the present study was to identify the species of Mortierella
associated with A. araucaria trees with symptoms of stem disease and to
evaluate their possible pathogenic role. Six species of Mortierella were
isolated from tissue affected. Results showed that M. alpina and M. aff.
basiparvispora were pathogenic to A. araucana, demonstrating the
involvement of Mortierellales in the decline of the tree.
